facts.text: Two firms obtained patentes to carry on business in Pondicherry in September 1954 for the first time.

anchor.surface_text: They have been filed by two firms who obtained patentes to carry on business in Pondicherry in September, 1954, for the first time. As the facts in all the petitions are similar, we shall only give the facts generally to understand the questions raised before us.

facts.text: Proprietor of one firm is resident of New Delhi, the other of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The two firms, it may be mentioned, did number carry on any business in Pondicherry before September, 1954, when they got a patente each and the proprietor of one of them is a resident of New Delhi while the proprietor of the other is a resident of Bombay.

facts.text: Administration of Pondicherry taken over by Union of India from November 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The administration of Pondicherry was taken over by the Union of India from November 1, 1954. Before that Pondicherry was under the administration of the Government of France and was a free port.

facts.text: Petitioners placed orders for import before August 15, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners case is that though the patentes were secured in September, 1954, orders for import were placed before August 15, 1954. Thereafter after authorisations had been obtained from the French authorities,

facts.text: Authorisations obtained from French authorities before November 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter after authorisations had been obtained from the French authorities, foreign exchange was acquired in the open market for the purpose of financing the import.

facts.text: Foreign exchange acquired in open market.

anchor.surface_text: foreign exchange was acquired in the open market for the purpose of financing the import. There were in all twenty-nine transactions by the two firms,

facts.text: Twenty-nine transactions subject of petitions.

anchor.surface_text: There were in all twenty-nine transactions by the two firms, which are the subject-matter of these petitions and in certain cases advances were paid,

facts.text: Shipments delayed due to dock strike in England and Continent and lack of shipping space; most after November 1, 1954; only three in October 1954.

anchor.surface_text: shipments companyld number be made because of an unexpected dock strike in England and on the Continent and also for want of shipping space, and therefore most of the companysignments on the basis of the twenty-nine orders were shipped after November 1, 1954, and only three companysignments out of twenty-nine companyld be shipped in October, 1954,

facts.text: Goods arrived at Pondicherry after November 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: that is, before the administration of Pondicherry was taken over by the Government of India. The goods in all these cases arrived at Pondicherry after November 1, 1954.

facts.text: S.R.O.s Nos. 3314 and 3315 issued by Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the administration of Pondicherry was taken over by the Government of India from November 1, 1954, in pursuance of an agreement between the Government of India and the Government of France, and two numberifications were issued by the Government of India, namely, S. R. O.s. Nos. 3314 and 3315.

facts.text: S.R.O. 3315 extended Sea Customs Act, 1878, etc., to Pondicherry with saving clause in para 6.

anchor.surface_text: By S. R. O. 3315, which was made under s,4 of the Foreign jurisdiction Act, No XLVII of 1947, the Sea Customs Act, 1878, the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934, the Imports and Exports  Control  Act, 1947, the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947, and the Indian Tariff Act, 1934, were extended to Pondicherry. This R.O. companytained a saving clause which laid down that-- Unless otherwise specially provided in the schedule,

facts.text: Press communique issued by Government of India on November 1, 1954, advising validation of licences.

anchor.surface_text: As a companysequence of these two S. R. O.s. a press companymunique was issued by the Government of India on November 1, 1954, explaining the effect of these numberifications, in which it was stated that imports into and exports from the French Establishments would be regulated in accordance with the provisions of the Imports and Exports  Control  Act, 1947.

facts.text: Petitioners applied for validation of authorisations, refused by Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, Pondicherry.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners then applied for validation of the authorisations, but the Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, Pondicherry refused to validate them.

facts.text: Collector of Customs refused clearance, issued show cause notices, ordered confiscation or penalties over Rs. 64,000 and Rs. 96,000.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually, when the goods arrived at Pondicherry after November 1, 1954, the petitioners approached the Collector of Customs at Pondicherry to permit clearance of the goods. They were number, however, allowed to clear them, and numberices were issued to them to show cause why the goods should number be forfeited on the ground that the import had been made in companytravention of the Imports and Exports  Control  Act, 1947 and the Sea Customs Act, 1878.

facts.text: Appeals to Central Board of Revenue dismissed, penalties reduced to over Rs. 35,000 and Rs. 60,000.

anchor.surface_text: There were then appeals by the petitioners before the Central Board of Revenue against the orders imposing penalties. These appeals were dismissed, though the penalty was reduced to over Rs.35,000/- in the case of one firm and Rs. 60,000/- in the case of other firm.

facts.text: Revisions to Government of India rejected on January 23, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners then went in revision to the Government of India but their revisions were rejected on January 23, 1957.

facts.text: Petitioners paid penalties and cleared goods.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the petitioners paid the penalty though the date is number clear from the petitions and cleared the goods.

facts.text: Messrs. Universal Imports Agency case decided on August 23, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Those petitions were decided on August 23, 1960 and this Court held that in view of para. 6 of S. R. O. 3315, already referred to,

facts.text: Present writ petitions filed in October 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the present writ petitions were filed in October, 1961.

facts.text: Collector of Customs found that orders not proven before August 15, 1954; firms started in September; no prior business; no correspondence.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector also pointed out that in the ordinary companyrse of business, companymitments were number made without entering into companyrespondence with the suppliers regarding the prices, terms of payment etc., but in these cases, the petitioners produced numbersuch companyrespondence. It was also found that the petitioners had number done any business of this kind even in the Indian Union before this.

facts.text: Press communique January 5, 1955, concessions for goods shipped before Nov 1 ordered before Aug 15.

anchor.surface_text: Later on January 5, 1955, the Union of India issued another press companymunique in view of certain representations received on the basis of Art. 17 of the Indo-French Agreement and the public was informed that import of goods against open market transactions after November 1, 1954, would be treated as unauthorised.

facts.text: Petitions heard on September 27, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. September 27. The judgment of Sinha, C. J., Gajendragadkar, Wanchoo and Shah, JJ., was delivered by Wanchoo, J., Das Gupta, J., delivered a separate Judgment.

facts.text: Court dismissed petitions as not maintainable under Art. 32 citing Ujjam Bai case.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the validity. of the orders impugned cannot be questioned in a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution. The petitions are hereby dismissed with companyts-one set of hearing companyts.

issues.text: Is an order of assessment made by an authority under a taxing statute which is intra vires, open to challenge as repugnant to Art. 19(1)(g), on the sole ground that it is based on a misconstruction of a provision of the Act or of a notification issued thereunder?

anchor.surface_text: Can the validity of such an order be questioned in a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution? issues.text: Whether a quasi-judicial authority acts without jurisdiction or wrongly assumes jurisdiction by committing an error as to a collateral fact, allowing challenge under Art. 32?

anchor.surface_text: without jurisdiction or wrongly assumes jurisdiction by committing an error as to a collateral fact and the resultant action threatens or violates a fundamental right the question of enforcement of that right arises and a petition under Art. 32 will lie.

holdings.text: The validity of the orders impugned cannot be questioned in a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the validity. of the orders impugned cannot be questioned in a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution. The petitions are hereby dismissed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quasi-judicial orders passed by competent authority under intra vires taxing statute (Sea Customs Act via S.R.O. 3315); challenge solely on misconstruction of para. 6 not permitted under Art. 32 per Ujjam Bai.

holdings.text: An order of assessment made by an authority under a taxing statute which is intra vires is not open to challenge as repugnant to Art. 19(1)(g) on the sole ground that it is based on a misconstruction of a provision of the Act or of a notification issued thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: Is an order of assessment made by an authority under a taxing statute which is intra vires, open to challenge as repugnant to Art. 19 1 g , on the sole ground that it is based on a misconstruction of a provision of the Act or of a notification issued thereunder?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts negative answer from majority in Ujjam Bai; applies analogously to customs penalty orders as 'taxing statute'; no violation of fundamental rights from mere erroneous construction.

holdings.text: The construction of para. 6 of S.R.O. 3315 must be deemed a construction of the Sea Customs Act itself.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.R.O. 3315 extends Acts including Sea Customs Act with para. 6 as saving clause akin to repealing/saving section; misconstruction thereof is misconstruction of extended Act.

holdings.text: In Messrs. Universal Imports Agency, authorities lacked right to confiscate due to misconstruction of para. 6, not inherent lack of jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: As we read the majority judgment, however, we do number find any warrant for coming to the conclusion that it was decided in that case that the authorities in that case had numberinherent jurisdiction to confiscate the goods or impose penalties in lieu thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Majority judgment held para. 6 saved transactions; no consideration of Art. 32 or jurisdiction issue; distinguishes from cases of inherent jurisdiction defect.

holdings.text: Collector of Customs had inherent jurisdiction to deal with the matter.

anchor.surface_text: It may be added that it is number disputed in this case that the Collector of Customs had inherent jurisdiction to deal with this matter and the only attack on his order aid on the subsequent orders passed in appeal and revision

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed; authority competent under s.167(8) Sea Customs Act read with Imports Control Act post S.R.O. 3315 extension.

holdings.text: Petitioners failed to prove orders placed before August 15, 1954; no reason to differ from Collector's factual finding.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector also pointed out that in the ordinary companyrse of business, companymitments were number made without entering into companyrespondence with the suppliers regarding the prices, terms of payment etc., but in these cases, the petitioners produced numbersuch companyrespondence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Firms new in Sept 1954, no prior business, no correspondence; pure finding of fact not interfering under Art. 32.

holdings.text: Petitioners did not raise para. 6 of S.R.O. 3315 before Collector; case rested on August 15 press concession, rejected on facts.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Collector addressed only pleaded case; no duty to consider unraised alternative; Board impliedly rejected para. 6 by holding licence required post-Nov 1.

holdings.text: If quasi-judicial authority acts without jurisdiction or wrongly assumes jurisdiction by error as to collateral fact violating fundamental right, Art. 32 petition lies.

anchor.surface_text: without jurisdiction or wrongly assumes jurisdiction by committing an error as to a collateral fact and the resultant action threatens or violates a fundamental right the question of enforcement of that right arises and a petition under Art. 32 will lie.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate judgment (Das Gupta J.); applies Ujjam Bai, State Trading Corp., Shoreditch; collateral fact here: contracts before Nov 1 determining Sea Customs applicability.

holdings.text: Materials produced insufficient to establish contracts concluded before November 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Coming number to the merits of the petitions, I need only state that the materials that have been produced by the petitioner are by numbermeans sufficient to establish the case that the contracts in these several cases were concluded before November 1, 1954.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate judgment; on merits after rejecting prelim obj; no further evidence needed as brethren dismissed on maintainability.
